awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Bluebird: Integrated IoT for Educators and Learners
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project develops a low-cost gateway for hands-on exploration and advances knowledge of Internet of things (IoT) fundamentals for educators and learners. The overarching goal of the project is to transform the current STEM landscape with an alternative, future-forward approach to designing connected devices, and to introduce a wide range of students to creative applications of complex technologies. Cyber-physical systems - commonly referred to as the Internet of things - are paving new information pathways and will soon become the foundation of all trades from medicine to publishing. These concepts need to be taught in a STEM curriculum but today are rarely even mentioned in a K-12 classroom. The end-product will help fulfill the NSF mission of preparing youth to lead scientific innovation and hold successful careers by building the technologies of the future. 

This Phase II project develops an unparalleled educational tool enabling users to build simple yet full-cycle IoT systems. The product exposes the underlying architecture of IoT and leads users through the concepts of electronics, collaborative coding, data security, and social impact. The main technical innovations are: 1) the design of small footprint, low-cost hardware with onboard communications components; and 2) the accompanying software platform that supports collaborative coding with multiple networked devices, while maintaining the highest level of security and privacy features to protect student data. Currently, IoT systems in the EdTech market have several layers of custom-built technology and outdated components. This project offers widely accessible hardware and software IoT building blocks with full functionality. Students will devise projects that activate objects remotely by giving them attributes, emotions, and behaviors. Additionally, they will gain awareness of the social implications of their projects, as they consider how the objects' attributes change and respond within the scope of a network and invent cause-and-effect interactions in an end-to-end IoT system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This Phase II project has resulted in the creation of the Tekniverse, a hardware and software ecosystem for teaching and learning how to design and build with networks devices, or the Internet of Things (IoT). This platform is intended for middle and highschool education environments in schools, museums, and camps. Tekniverse exposes the layers of IoT, inviting learners to participate in the process and create their own networks. We have additionally started testing the platform as a tool for designers to quickly prototype interactive projects.

In Phase I of the project we developed an MVP of the hardware end device in multiple form factors and designed a native App for programming the hardware and analyzing data from incoming sensors. 

The original goal for Phase II was to continue to develop these native Apps and create an online learning management system. However, due to the tremendous global change in education, resources, and lifestyle caused by the Covid19 pandemic, we shifted in Phase II to developing a web-based version of our software tools. We also prioritized features that would promote remote collaboration, social emotional learning, and self directed learning as these were pain points with remote learning. To this end, focused on designing more student-to-student interactions and developed projects where students could use their homes as an explorative learning space when they did not have access to schools and libraries. 

The end devices of Tekniverse are primarily based around Bluebird, our easy-to-use Bluetooth-enabled printed circuit board built around the nRF52840 chipset.  Bluebird leverages the nRF52840?s integrated USB 2.0 controller for both drag-and-drop programming and debugging without requiring any additional hardware. Bluebird includes a 6-axis accelerometer, light/color sensor, piezo speaker, Neopixel LED, and temperature sensor.  

The design of Bluebird took place in multiple iterations, focusing on usability, cost, and power efficiency. In terms of usability, we optimized for a set of onboard components that would offer an exciting and diverse range of example projects without additional hardware requirements. We have developed several hardware accessories for Bluebird including a battery powered shield, an LED matrix, and a WIFI shield. In addition to our Bluebird, users can use Tekniverse with other BLE (Bluetooth Low Energy) end devices through a subscription purchase. Though these functions are more limited, we felt a need to expand accessibility in this way, especially with manufacturing delays caused by the pandemic.

As for the software, there are two main components of Tekniverse: Control Center functions as a data dashboard consisting of graphs and a simulation of Bluebird, or other end device you are using.  As you click on different parts of the simulation, like the LED, you can trigger the onboard LED to change colors. With just a Bluetooth connection that data coming in is considered ?local?. When a user goes "live" with their board, their data can be streamed by a collaborator from any location through the Internet, creating an experience where students and educators can feel as if they are physically looking over each other's shoulders, sharing discovery and excitement. Code Builder offers an intuitive Block-based coding playground consisting of a toolbox of codeblocks and a coding canvas, where programs are constructed. If users have live collaborators they can work on the coding canvas together in real time. In addition to custom tools we have developed libraries to use Bluebird with popular open source coding environments including Arduino and Makecode.

We have commercialized the platform and sold several hundred Bluebirds to date including for an ongoing collaboration in Alaska where students are using Tekniverse to learn about earthquakes and other factors leading to climate change in the region. Tekniverse has impacted the lives of many teachers and students by providing a gateway into exploring complex technologies. We are hoping to work on more projects that focus on environmental and community science going forward as this pilot was very successful. We have also prototyped an at home kit which we plan to launch in 2023. We have partnerships with large educational projects where we will implement Bluebird with local schools over the next few years. In addition to hardware sales we have created a licensable version of the software with support from TECP funding. 

 

This platform is live at https://tekniverse.teknikio.com where anyone can enter the Tekniverse and dive into the world of IoT.  Here you can find several free tools, links to native Apps, and hardware purchases.
